text:
Read The Full Script Here

Today’s show is sponsored by the Electric Vehicle Association! Join up to support the electrification of transport today!

And by Energy Sage! Plan your energy independence and insulate yourself from rising energy costs today!

And by you! Stick around to find out how you can help us remain one hundred percent independent!

Welcome back to another episode of TEN — Transport Evolved News! Thanks for joining me.

Before I delve into today’s show I want to acknowledge that the news cycle is a shit show right now in the EV world. And that means a lot of today’s show will delve into politics and yeah, it’s going to be tough going. I don’t want to sugar coat this – politics matters – and those who say it doesn’t come from a place of privilege they’re not willing to acknowledge. So please, don’t blame us for covering political stories that are relevant to the EV world.

And we start with one such story – namely that the U.S. Government has officially published plans to slash fuel economy standards for cars and light trucks.

Standing with the CEOs of Ford and Stellantis, President Trump ripped into previous standard set by President Biden, calling them illegal and blaming them for the high cost of cars (even though I and many watching will blame unwanted in-car tech). Slashing nearly a third off the twenty-thirty-one target of fifty- point four miles per gallon, the new target is thirty-four point five miles per gallon – less than automakers managed fleet wide last year. We’re already seeing automakers push away from EVs toward more heavily polluting engines – like V-8s – even when their portfolios include more efficient, cheaper engines and drivetrains. And that only signals bad things ahead for everyone. But maybe there’s hope for one thing: kei cars. President Trump says he wants them to be allowed in the U.S., after seeing them on his trip to Japan. And given we’re now ruled by Presidential whim in the U.S…. Well… yah.

That Presidential whim – and continued attacks on EVs have seen what all of us predicted come to pass: a meteoric drop in EV sales during November.

Ford, which has indefinitely paused all F150 Lightning production – reported a sixty point eight percent drop in EV sales during November, replaced by a surge in gas-guzzling SUV sales. Meanwhile, Honda’s Prologue EV sales dropped eighty-six percent, despite large cash-on-hood incentives for buyers. At the time of filming, GM hasn’t published its November figures, but they’re not expected to be good. Hyundai and Kia also had a terrible November, with sales drops of more than one half for both brands. Meanwhile, pretty much every automaker recorded increases in hybrid sales.

We’re off to the UK now, where in addition to trying to legally erase and ban people like me from actually existing outside of their homes, the UK government is doing its best to mimic the USA.

Its just-released budget confirmed that while the government will be extending EV incentives until twenty-thirty, it also wants to tax EV and plug-in hybrid owners three pence per mile. Granted, the budget does include commitments to address the cost of EV charging, and to work on making it easier to install charging for people without off-street parking – but the data from November sales is already very dour. While EV sales in November were up one point five percent on the same period last year, with EVs now accounting for twenty-six point four percent of the new car market, the growth rate of EV adoption is the lowest it’s been in three years.

Luckily though, not every country in the world is making EVs the problem, and in Norway, we’ve got further demonstration of how amazing EV incentives can be to adoption rates.

This week, figures from November show that EVs accounted for more than ninety-seven point six percent of all new vehicles registered in the country. – but thanks to a rise in competitive pricing deals, Norway set new records for car registrations for the year, with just shy of twenty-thousand vehicles hitting the roads. That’s nearly double the number of cars sold in October. And while the Norwegian government had toyed with the idea of rolling back its VAT exemption on EV from twenty twenty-seven, a compromise reached this week will keep VAT exemption for EVs until twenty twenty-eight, with a new user limit of one hundred and fifty-thousand kroner in twenty twenty-seven, half of what it will be next year.

As some governments around the world sour on an all-electric future, we’re starting to see automakers take advantage of the situation and push back plans to go all -electric.

This week, reporting from Bloomberg suggests BMW, which has maintained it wants an electrified future – is now considering reintroducing its range-extended EV architecture for future models. The report claims that BMW is examining the reintroduction of REx – Range-Extending Engines – for its X5 and 7-Series models in China. It’s worth noting that the reporting is referring to engines connected to a generator that will provide electricity to an EV drivetrain when the car’sbatteries are empty, rather than traditional plug-in hybrid setups where the engine can drive the wheels in some situations. BMW has not refuted nor confirmed the reporting, stating that it is continually refining its plans based on customer and market trends.

Aptera has officially published its newest video update this week showing off its Validation Vehicle Assembly line for the first time.

The company – which is working to bring its three-wheeled solar electric car to market – is still very much using a pretty manual production process at this time, but what makes this line different from what went before is the extensive use of specialized assembly jigs to speed up component installation onto the pre-assembled bodies – complete with battery packs that Aptera’s battery partner CTNS is now building on site. This is the first time CTNS has build battery modules at Aptera’s facility, lowering build costs and lead times. With validation assembly under way – the company says it’s continuing its final testing a pace, and says that its combined cycle testing – high speed, stop and go, and urban – are quote ‘encouraging’. It’s hoping to engage in final regulatory testing soon. Watch this space.

Hyundai’s EV sales may have taken a hit last month in the U.S., but that hasn’t stopped its luxury arm, Genesis, from showing off its newest, highest-performance EV yet: the GV60 Magma.

Revealed in France this week, the model is a new upper-end variant of the GV60, with redesigned front body components and an all-wheel-drive system that rockets from zero to two hundred kilometers per hour (that’s zero to one hundred twenty-five miles per hour) in ten point nine seconds. A head-up display is standard, and the seats are wrapped in a suede-like material called Chamude. Official range figures for most markets aren’t out yet, but this is clearly a car built to go fast and think about range second. For the curious, it somehow keeps the mighty orb… because it wouldn’t be a GV60 without it.

Genesis also revealed its newest concept, the Magma GT, hinting at the brand’s future direction.

While some markets have yet to experience BYD’s EVs thanks to protectionist policies wrapped up as cybersecurity concerns, BYD has just celebrated a new milestone for its BYD Dolphin: 1 Million Global Sales.

On sale in its home market since twenty twenty-one and welcomed to Europe in twenty twenty-three, the Dolphin EV — not to be confused with its smaller sibling, the Seagull (or Dolphin Surf in Europe) — celebrated its half-millionth model late twenty twenty-three after twenty-five months in production – and the one millionth model hasn’t taken a long time to arrive after. With a choice of forty-five point one two kilowatt-hour or sixty point four-eight kilowatt-hour battery packs, the Dolphin holds its own in the already-crowded C-Segment in Europe, fighting off far more stablished brands, like Peugeot, Citroen and Renault in the EV space.

Over the past few years, we’ve seen plenty of developments made in the sector of wireless inductive charging for EVs – both in the passenger car and light-duty segment.

This week however, researchers at Purdue University carried out the first successful real-world test of a dynamic high-power inductive charging system fitted to a class-eight electric big rig on a quarter-mile stretch of US Highway 52 and US Highway 231 in West Lafayette Indiana. Using a specially-modified electric tractor built by Cummins, the system successfully transmitted one hundred and ninety kilowatts from the road to the truck while it was traveling along at sixty-five miles per hour (or about one hundred and four kilometers per hour). While the press release doesn’t go into details, my back-of-the-napkin calculations suggest that’s more than enough to cover all — or at least a significant portion — of the energy requirements for a fully loaded Class 8 big rig, if this system were extended over a meaningful distance.

And finally for this segment, some good news. While the U.S. White House continues its war on renewables, data from the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission shows that renewables are still ascendent in the Energy Generation Landscape.

Its latest report, published this week, shows that of the new generation capacity added to the U.S. electrical grid from January through until the End of September, and astonishing eighty-eight percent came from renewables. In fact, for twenty-five months straight, Solar has dominated new solar generating capacity – and I should note here that FERC only tracks grid-scale solar, not domestic solar. Today, nearly one third of all U.S. electricity generation comes from grid-scale renewable projects, with domestic solar pushing it well over that figure. If things continue, solar will become the second-largest source of U.S. Grid Generation, second only to natural gas.

And if you’re in the U.S., and want to lower your reliance on imported energy or grid power, it’s time to talk to our friends at Energy Sage!

Energy Sage connects you with local, verified solar installers across the United States — and now heat pump specialists in select markets — who really know their stuff and can help guide you through installing solar panels or getting a heat pump. Not a homeowner? No worries. Energy Sage can still help you green your electricity by joining a community solar program!

We used Energy Sage ourselves when looking for installers willing to put solar panels on our roof, and their verified pros were knowledgeable and even introduced us to a great credit union to finance the project with low monthly payments.

While the U.S. Federal Tax Incentives for solar end at the end of this year, you still may be able to squeeze in an install before the big ball drops on January first, so act now if you’ve been putting it off!

Follow the links below to sign up for Energy Sage’s free, no-obligation service and get started today! And if you choose an Energy Sage installer, we’ll receive a small referral fee — so you’ll be helping us too! Help the grid get greener, save money, gain energy independence, and support our show — it’s a win-win-win-win!

We’re off to Recall Reminders now — and as a reminder, full details are on our website if these affect you!

Ford is recalling its Escape and Lincoln Corsair plug-in hybrids to address a potential short circuit condition in affected cars’ battery packs. Owners are being asked to only use “auto EV mode”.

BYD is recalling around ninety-thousand Q’in Plus DM-i plug-in hybrids in China to address potential battery issues causing what it says are performance limitations.

And finally for the recalls, Hyundai is recalling certain twenty twenty-five IONIQ 5 EVs after noting that the seat belt retractors for the front seats may not be securely fastened. A recall campaign will begin in January.

And those are your recall reminders! Now it’s time for our news shorts. As always, full links to all the stories are on our website. There’s a link for the relevant post in this episode’s description.

Lotus has has confirmed that it will be debuting its first plug-in hybrid next year. The company had originally promised to go fully-electric, but the new announcement of a plug-in hybrid changes that.

The Canadian government has announced more than ten million Canadian dollars of funding to help accelerate EV adoption across the nation. It include nine million for EV infrastructure, plus more than one point four million to electric motor research.

MAN truck and bus is working with logistics service partner VEGA International to use all-electric MAN trucks to deliver other all-electric MAN trucks. It’s both advertising and emissions-lowering.

BYD has just celebrated its best-sales figures for this year, selling just shy of half a million EVs during November. However, its sales figures are down a little on the same period last year.

Audi is tweaking five of its models for the new year – including the A6 e-tron and Q6 e-tron. New improvements include a promised energy efficiency boost, though Audi has not shared official figures.

A twenty twenty-four lawsuit filed by Einride against A.P. Moller Maersk has become public. While the case is ongoing, both sides give a different version of events, revolving around an electric truck service in the U.S.

Mercedes-Benz has officially published U.S. pricing for its all-new CLA EV. Starting from forty-seven thousand, two hundred and fifty US dollars, it will cross-shop against the Mustang Mach E and Model 3.

CATL, working with Autoflight, has unveiled a new zero-carbon water vertiport designed to integrate sea and air travel. There’s no confirmed location, but a water-size demo did take place in China.

The French Government has confirmed that it will be extending its EV purchase incentive programs through until next year. The incentives are focused on lower-income citizens seeking to go electric.

Mining company BHP has welcomed the first two purpose-built battery-electric locomotives to its Australian rail fleet. Built by Wabtec, the units are fully-electric, and will work in Western Australia.

Hyundai is officially expanding its V2X services around the world, aiming to facilitate the adoption of V2X and V2G services for all Hyundai, Kia, and Genesis EV owners. It will include expanded smart charging and V2G capabilities in Europe, and V2G services in the U.S.

Motor Specialist Yasa has just celebrated building its fifty thousandth axial flux motor. The UK firm supplies high-performance motors to many hypercard manufacturers for use in Hybrids and EVs.

Ford Europe is booming the battery capacity of its passenger-carrying e-Tourneo Custom for the new model year, with a new seventy kilowatt-hour battery pack up six kilowatt-hours on last year’s model.

BYD has announced that it’s expanding its battery warranty in Norway to eight years or a quarter million kilometers. It previously offered two hundred thousand kilometer warranties.

A class action lawsuit is gaining traction against Tesla over bricked Powerwalls that were intentionally drained by Tesla as part of an ongoing safety recall. Claimants say Tesla left them with a wall decoration.

Volkswagen commercial vehicles has announced that its ID Buzz Cargo will come with a long wheelbase option in European markets for the first time, along with a larger eighty-six kilowatt-hour battery.

Solaris Bus has announced a new program designed to allow fleet owners of older Solaris buses the ability to upgrade their buses battery packs to the latest-generation ones. Some of Solaris’ electric buses are now more than ten years old.

The U.S. Department of Transportation has just unveiled more than two billion dollars in grant funding to modernize bus fleets in the U.S. – but not a single dime is being awarded for battery electric buses.

CATL has made a bolt prediction this week that within three years, it will have electric boat battery packs that are powerful enough to allow electric ocean-going boats capable of cross-ocean travel.

Piaggio has debuted its Porter NPE – an all-electric version of its already-in production micro truck. The four-wheeler is designed for work duties in tight spaces and emission-controlled zones.

YASA has confirmed that it is working on an in-wheel drive system for electric vehicles that makes use of its twelve point seven kilo axial flux motor. Yasa is owned by Mercedes-Benz, and its motors featured in the AMG Concept GT XX.

Denmark’s just-published sales figures for November shows that three-quarters of all new cars registered in the nation were all-electric. The most popular model? The Skoda Elroq.

Despite the best efforts of the White House to cancel the deployment of electric mail trucks, the U.S. postal Service has confirmed it’s already welcome eight thousand, five hundred EVs to its fleet.

Archer Aviation has announced that it will be working with Related Ross and Magic City Innovation District to establish an Air Tax Network in Miami Florida. It will serve multiple tourist locations.

The designer behind the controversial Jaguar Type 00 electric concept is apparently no-longer at the firm. As reported this week, the executive was allegedly fired and escorted out of the office this week.

After a troubling few months, EV company Bollinger Motors is no more. Originally intended to bring a rugged off-roader to market, its transition to a commercial truck company didn’t do it any favors.

Morris Commercial Limited has announced that it has chosen a facility in Wales to be the site of its all-electric J-Type EV – the Morris JE. It is styled on the classic Morris commercial vehicle of the nineteen fifties.

Toyota has announced a series of strategic partnerships in Europe that it hopes will enable it to offer customers smart grid and V2G services in Europe. Details are a little sparse, but watch this space.

Researchers at the Max Planck Institute for Polymer Research, with Japanese partners, have mapped space-charge layers in solid-state batteries, offering insights that could help make higher-performance, denser cells.

Hyundai held a topping-out-ceremony this week at its new future mobility Battery Campus in South Korea. The facility is planned to be operational by the end of next year, and help the firm develop new EV battery cells.

The Coalition government in Germany has agreed on a new proposal to counter the EU’s twenty-thirty-five zero emission vehicle requirements. It wants the EU to permit “highlight-efficient ICE” models alongside EVs. It will submit its proposals to the EU later this month.

The UK Department for Transport has clarified rules on commercial electric vans to exempt them from the weight restrictions that would otherwise mean they would classify as heavy-goods vehicles – requiring a different driver’s license to operate them.

Stellantis, working with CATL, has officially started construction of a new LFP battery production facility in Spain. CATL has sent two thousand workers to the region to support construction.

Gridserve and the EXTRA service station chain in the UK have announced an expansion of EV charging along UK motorways. The new EV Super hubs will offer expanded EV charging options.

German electric scooter company Govecs has filed for insolvency. Its 50cc equivalent electric scooter is inspired by east-german two-strokes from before the wall fell – but its future now remains uncertain.

Sales data from India has confirmed that the nation has set a new record for EV sales, selling its two millionth EV in a single year with one full calendar month left before the end of the year.

Fiat has made some slight tweaks to the all-electric Grande Panda in the UK. There’s a new Pop trim, offering functional, but basic EV motoring for those on a tight budget.

Sticking with the UK, with Omoda and Jaecoo EVs not eligible for EV tax incentives in the country, both brands – owned by Chery – have announced their own incentive program in the form of in-house rebates.

And finally for the news shorts, the UK post office is welcoming eight new all-electric heavy-goods-vehicles to its fleet, further electrifying the nation’s postal service.,

Our final two stories are next, but first, a word from you.

For over fifteen years—ten in the U.S.—I and the TE team have been bringing you news on cleaner, greener, safer, smarter, and more equitable transportation and energy. We’re not backed by corporations, and we don’t have huge production budgets. Our tiny team—three full-time and one part-time member—works hard every week to bring you well-researched, honest content.

When we started, YouTube ad revenue paid the bills. These days, like most independent creators, ad revenue has dropped sharply. Worse, YouTube often sidelines diverse voices, overlooks minority creators, and prioritizes clickbait and AI fluff over real content. We wouldn’t exist without your support at Patreon.com/TransportEvolved.

I hate doing this, but here it is: just this week, a $4,200 annual E&O insurance bill arrived. Even though it’s yearly, it hits like a monthly expense—on top of team salaries, health insurance, retirement plans, and keeping the lights on. Health insurance alone has gone up forty percent this year. We keep a tight rein on our finances and have buffers, but right now, we’re treading water rather than growing—and costs are going up. I even fund part of the channel from my partner’s income, and that’s not sustainable. In an ideal world, we wouldn’t have to ask for your support… but here we are. It’s better than putting everything behind a paywall, which I am most certainly and vehemently against.

To keep producing videos—and to keep this channel alive—we need a budget boost. Even a thousand dollars a month—less than ten percent of what it costs to run this channel, which itself is about ten percent of the budget of much larger channels—would make a huge difference and let us sleep easier at night.

Even a single dollar helps. We’ve added new Patreon tiers for every budget, so if you already support us, thank you—it keeps this show alive.

And now… it’s time for those last two stories. Both of them from the UK.

Apparently, Brits like tea. A lot. And, as someone who is part British, I can attest that yes, I do indeed like a cup of tea to keep me going in the afternoon. Although in the morning, I’m all about Coffee.

But this week, Stellantis brand Vauxhall – which is basically the UK twin to Opel – took its UK roots and ran with it, announcing its new elect-ric-it-tea van. It’s a very obvious pun on electricity and consists of a Vauxhall Vivaro electric van that features a fully-kitted out kitchen behind its central sliding door. The company cites lots of research stating that most tradespeople say they’d prefer to stop and have a cup of tea in the afternoon that they themselves had made, and decided to make this advertising campaign around it. Now, it’s a neat, fun little concept, complete with sink, coffee, tea, fresh milk, and even some chocolate digestives (or maybe hobnobs). But there’s one flaw: I don’t know a single tradesperson with a van – electric or otherwise – that has room inside for all their gear and a fully-fitted kitchen. A smarter option? An electric kettle plugged into an on-board V2L system.

And finally,

If you’re an EV driver and you have any experience of public charging, you might know that when you plug in to a fast charger, the cable is locked in position by your car for your – and its safety.

When the charging session ends, the cable is supposed to release, but sometimes – if the charging session fails or there’s an error in the car the lock doesn’t release, causing panic and frustration. Most EVs today come with a hidden release cable that allow you to safely disconnect, but most owners don’t know about it. And, apparently, that’s led many people in the UK to call 999 – the UK equivalent of 911 – for assistance. This week, the London metropolitan police got so fed up with the number of calls from hapless EV owners asking for assistance that it had to issue a public statement reminding people that having your car stuck on a charging station is – and never should be – an emergency services call. Sure, if there’s a fire that’s different, but my advice is to learn where your EVs’ emergency release cable is. Most (but not all) have them.

And on that note, we’re done for today’s show.

But first, a huge thank you to the Electric Vehicle Association for sponsoring today’s show. The EVA has been advocating for electric vehicles since nineteen sixty-seven and remains firmly committed to a cleaner, greener future for all. Join the EVA today to find out how to become an EV educator, meet like-minded fans, and get help to make your own transition to electric, help that includes a low-interest loan program to help finance your next step! Find out more at myeva dot org.

And thanks to EnergySage! Follow the link below to plan your own energy-independent future before those tax credits vanish.

And thanks to you – if you can, please consider supporting us from just one dollar and fifty cents a month on Patreon. As I mentioned earlier, running a small YouTube channel like this isn’t cheap – and without your support, we’d not exist. So please do consider supporting us if you’re able – and remember that supporting us can also include sharing our content, joining our Discord chat room, promoting us on social media, or using our affiliate links — all in the down below. Oh, and for those looking to make one-off donations, don’t forget we have a PO Box – and a Ko-Fi – both of which are great ways to make one-off payments!

We publish every Tuesday, Thursday, and Saturday here — and every Sunday we drop two videos on Transport Evolved Take Two!

And in closing, some important words:

You are valid. You are loved. You belong. You have a purpose.

This week has seen more marginalization, more hate, and more othering of people in our lives and our communities. More bans, more threatened deportations and worse. And while the person in charge doesn’t already represent a nation or even the majority of people in it, it can be hard to want to carry on carrying on. But in order to change history – we need resistance – and intentionality.

Engage in Tactical Frivolity. Don’t surrender to fear, hate, or misinformation. That’s as true in Portland, Oregon, as it is anywhere power and greed seek to crush the will of ordinary people. Don’t buy into division and cruelty. Empathy is a skill we must practice daily to preserve our shared humanity. Just like humor, it’s an act of radical resistance.

But everyone needs time out. Unplug, get outside, dive into a good book, go gardening, or do a run, and recharge. Care for yourself and your loved ones now, so you can return ready to fight for decency, community, justice, and a better world. Let your light shine — in or outside an inflatable frog costume.

Wherever you are, whoever you are, whoever you love — you are not alone. Be an ally. Be kind. Be the change you want to see. Don’t let hate or ignorance win. As always, keep evolving!

title: COP30 in Belém: Joint Effort, Tensions and a Path to the End of Fossil Fuels - Fair Observer
authors: Luiz Villares, Abubakar Iqbal Sheikh, Muhammad Zulfikar Rakhmat
description:
The presidency also proposed reformulating climate finance reporting, linking it to the New Collective Quantified Goal for Climate Finance (NCQG), seeking greater transparency between “provided” and “mobilized” resources.
Even so, the efforts of Brazilian climate leadership deserve attention and recognition.
By shifting the debate to a dedicated forum with technical and political focus, the coalition creates space to build operational consensus, finance transition guarantees and design social and labor protections.
This parallel path is a necessary complement to global negotiations on the planet’s foremost climate agenda: ending the use of fossil fuels.
Civil society demanded ambition, integrity of information and climate justice — reinforcing that serious policy must articulate science, human rights and broad social participation.
text:
The holding of the 30th UN Climate Change Conference (COP30) in Belém made history for two complementary reasons: it was the first climate conference hosted in the Amazon, and it put forests, Indigenous peoples and civil society back at the center of climate negotiations. Bringing together 195 countries and culminating in the unanimous adoption of 29 decisions, the conference showed that, despite geopolitical contradictions and obstacles, there is still room for collective progress.

The key points of Belém were the “joint decision,” the shifting positions of the European Union, the objections of large oil-producing countries and the enormous efforts of Brazilian diplomatic coordination to deliver on implementation of the Paris Agreement. In parallel with the diplomatic conference, Belém welcomed a vigorous presence of civil society, a powerful expression of its commitment to social justice in the fight against climate change.

The decision to join forces: strategy, scope and limits

In the context of the climate negotiations, the Brazilian presidency of the COP created the Mutirão — a “joint decision” strategy to untangle sensitive issues and stitch together a single package of decisions that included finance, adaptation, just transition, trade, gender and technology. At the end of the conference, this package resulted in the approval of 29 documents that sought to advance on multiple fronts without leaving behind urgent demands from the Global South.

Among the financial measures approved, concrete allocations of $135 million to the Adaptation Fund and $300 million to adapt the health sector to climate impacts stand out. The presidency also proposed reformulating climate finance reporting, linking it to the New Collective Quantified Goal for Climate Finance (NCQG), seeking greater transparency between “provided” and “mobilized” resources.

On the other hand, financial ambition fell short of what was necessary: the task-force proposal foresees tripling adaptation financing by 2035 compared with 2025, but without a clearly defined base value. This gap reflects the historical difficulty of the multilateral system in translating political commitment into measurable financial flows — a challenge that, according to climate finance experts, is reflected in the current adaptation finance gap, estimated at around $340 billion. This amount is forecast to reach $1.35 trillion by 2035.

No binding target was delivered to finance adaptation, and the multilateral ambition to mobilize trillions for clean infrastructure remains without clear accountability mechanisms. The recognition that historical goals have not been met gained space in the final text, but without new and effective structures that guarantee the flow of resources where they are most urgent.

Among other points in the task-force decision, advances were made on information integrity and the fight against climate disinformation — essential to confronting denialism, including disinformation promoted by parts of the fossil-fuel industry. There were also developments on carbon markets and discussions on high-integrity rules — a necessary subject for robust accounting of carbon credits, which remains controversial given cases of fraud and technical errors worldwide.

The EU’s position: defensive pragmatism

The European Union played a decisive role in the final design of the “joint decision”. European officials adopted a pragmatic stance: supporting the negotiated package as long as it did not include provisions they considered unfeasible or unsupported, especially those related to the energy transition. In negotiations, European representatives conditioned their greater willingness to finance adaptation on the inclusion — from their point of view — of balanced measures in the energy transition.

This stance produced two key effects: (1) the EU helped ensure approval of the package, avoiding a total impasse; (2) at the same time, its bargaining limited the financial ambition of the final text, contributing to less binding wording on goals and responsibilities. Observers interpreted this strategy as a balance between pro-climate rhetoric and cautious practice — especially relevant after the United States’s direct absence, which altered traditional leadership dynamics.

Objections from Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, China, India and Russia: blocking the fossil roadmap

One of the most sensitive points in the Belém negotiations was the so‑called “roadmap” for moving away from an economy dependent on fossil fuels — an explicit priority of the Brazilian presidency. Although the initiative gained important political support, especially from the Global South and activist leaders, it did not make it into the final texts due to a lack of consensus. Fossil-fuel-producing countries (notably Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates), as well as major emitters such as China and India, and to a lesser extent, Russia, and even Japan, raised firm objections.

These objections ranged from practical issues (timing, socioeconomic impacts and energy security) to geopolitical positions defending industrial and revenue interests. For many of these countries, formal commitments to abandon fossil fuels would entail high political and economic costs, requiring guarantees of finance, technology transfer and just treatment for workers and communities. This bloc managed to bar inclusion of the roadmap in the joint decision, relegating it to a parallel initiative — albeit one that faces growing political pressure.

Brazilian diplomatic leadership: sewing consensus and maintaining the agenda

Brazil, as COP30 president, worked intensively to transform the mutirão effort into a political reality. The presidency’s strategy combined multilateral diplomacy (bilateral and multilateral negotiations), global visibility — placing the Amazon at the center of discussions — and bridge-building among groups of countries. The presidency proposed the creation of an international just-transition mechanism, with a draft to be presented by June 2026 and contributions open until March 15, 2026, aiming to establish an instrument to organize finance, technical cooperation and capacity building.

This action produced results: 122 countries presented new Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs) during COP30, and a package of decisions elevated just transition as an institutional priority. However, the Brazilian effort coexists with internal contradictions — part of the government promoted a roadmap for renewables even as the state authorized oil exploration auctions at the mouth of the Amazon, renewed contracts for gas and coal thermal plants through 2040, and faced a Congress about to review vetoes and make environmental licensing more flexible.

These internal tensions erode the policy coherence needed to transform international commitments into robust domestic policies. Even so, the efforts of Brazilian climate leadership deserve attention and recognition.

Colombia–Netherlands initiative: a promising path to the end of fossil fuels

Facing the impasse on including the energy transition roadmap, Colombia and the Netherlands launched a joint initiative to organize the first international conference on “Just Transition Away from Fossil Fuels” in April 2026. This initiative deserves attention and applause for inaugurating an alternative strategic path to the unanimity-based system of UN climate conferences. It points to a promising mobilization of more than 80 countries to address the transition from coal, oil and gas to renewable energies, in parallel with COP processes.

By shifting the debate to a dedicated forum with technical and political focus, the coalition creates space to build operational consensus, finance transition guarantees and design social and labor protections. This parallel path is a necessary complement to global negotiations on the planet’s foremost climate agenda: ending the use of fossil fuels.

Civil society, Indigenous peoples and the pulse of climate democracy

Belém experienced one of the highest levels of civil society participation in COP history after three years of conferences in less receptive environments for public demonstrations. At COP30, more than 3,000 Indigenous people engaged inside and outside the negotiations, defending territorial rights among many demands; hundreds of parallel events addressed themes related to the Amazon’s socioenvironmental values and standing-forest bioeconomy. The streets were filled with a march estimated at 70,000 people — a clear popular demonstration for global climate action. Science was prominent: a scientific pavilion brought climate scientists into direct contact with the COP presidency.

Civil society demanded ambition, integrity of information and climate justice — reinforcing that serious policy must articulate science, human rights and broad social participation. The launch of the Tropical Forests Forever Fund (TFFF), which raised nearly $7 billion, was welcomed by some sectors; others criticized its governance and reliance on private funds, reflecting the debate on financing forest protection without offloading public responsibility.

The end of deforestation by 2030 is an imperative for Brazil to reach its NDC. Efforts have been made to decrease present deforestation to reasonable levels, which will continue in the coming years. Nevertheless, the TFFF figures and other funding sources suggest that they are below the zero-deforestation ambition needs.

The event also exposed shortcomings in COP infrastructure: thermal discomfort in the Amazon heat and humidity, and a small fire that was quickly controlled but interrupted use of some spaces for an afternoon and led to a few hospital visits without major consequences.

What lies ahead

At the slow pace of consensus-based diplomacy, attention now turns to COP31 in Turkey, with Australia chairing negotiations. Key points to watch for a minimally positive meeting include guaranteed and meaningful inclusion of civil society; a real commitment by hosts to halt approval of new coal projects; concrete progress on adaptation finance with numerical targets; operationalization of the just-transition mechanism; and consolidation of technical processes that make the fossil-fuel roadmap a negotiable agenda rather than mere rhetoric. A Pre-COP in the Pacific, responding to the needs of island states threatened by sea-level rise, and the selection of a negotiation president with the capacity to unite interests will be decisive.

COP30 in Belém renewed the political agenda by placing the Amazon at the heart of negotiations and by structuring a joint package of decisions that seeks to reconcile justice, adaptation and transition. At the same time, it made clear that without binding financial commitments, consistent social inclusion and domestic policy coherence, progress will be slow.

The Colombia–Netherlands initiative for a conference dedicated to ending fossil fuels is a promising beacon: it offers a technical-political forum to translate political pressure from Belém into concrete measures. If Brazilian diplomacy and global coalitions can convert the “joint decisions” momentum into operational instruments and real finance, COP30 may be remembered as the starting point of a historic turning point — led, above all, by the civil society that occupied Belém and demonstrated that the world wants, and can, accelerate the transition away from fossil fuels.

Geopolitical conflicts and multilateral fissures persist, but Brazilian leadership at this COP advanced agendas despite contradictions. The resistance of oil-producing countries and the absence of the United States shaped resistance to consensus-based diplomatic agreements. Still, Belém sent a strong signal from civil society and a considerable coalition of countries willing to pursue the end of fossil fuels — a positive and promising outcome for a polarized world dominated by the capital of the old fossil economy.

[Kaitlyn Diana edited this piece.]

text:
Global manufacturing solutions provider Jabil is expanding its partnership with metal parts manufacturer Inno to enhance the production of battery energy storage system (BESS) enclosures.

The move could strengthen the supply chain for a technology that is fundamental to the worldwide transition toward renewable energy.

Their collaboration includes a joint investment in a 15,000-square-metre facility in Rayong, Thailand, which is expected to begin prototyping in late 2026.

Bolstering the BESS value chain

Battery energy storage is crucial for creating a more flexible and resilient energy system. As renewable generation from sources like wind and solar expands, BESS technology fulfils a critical function. It allows for the storage of energy when it is plentiful and its release to the grid during periods of peak demand, or when generation is low stabilising the system and reducing reliance on fossil fuels.

The partnership between Jabil and Inno – a subsidiary of Shanghai Xinpeng Industry Co. (XP) – builds on a relationship that dates back to 2014. The new facility in Rayong will focus specifically on manufacturing BESS metal enclosures. These components can represent a large portion of overall system costs because of raw material expenses and complex welding requirements.

Traditionally, manufacturers have sourced these enclosures from China before shipping them for final integration in markets closer to the end user. This expanded partnership could enable Jabil to offer a comprehensive lifecycle solution for BESS customers. The process includes sheet metal processing structural section fabrication welding and coating all from a single cost-effective location.

The site’s position just 25km from Laem Chabang, Thailand’s largest port, provides strategic access to global shipping lanes. By localising these manufacturing processes the collaboration could help simplify sourcing and reduce the carbon footprint associated with long-distance transportation.

Building supply chain resilience

Diversifying the supply chain for renewable energy components is becoming increasingly important. Geopolitical uncertainty and tariffs have highlighted the risks of relying on a single region for critical parts. The new Thailand facility offers an alternative manufacturing hub, helping to create a more robust and resilient supply network for the energy sector.

"For over a decade," says Brent Tompkins, SVP, Global Business Units, Renewables and Energy Infrastructure, "our team has helped energy storage leaders design and integrate technologies like battery management systems power electronics and high-level assemblies into their BESS solutions.

"Our customers are increasingly looking to diversify their supply chain in the face of tariffs and geopolitical uncertainty. We're excited to offer this critical industry a vertically integrated solution that meets their needs from enclosure production to final integration and fulfilment while simplifying sourcing and reducing risk."

Supporting a sustainable energy future

The collaboration is positioned to support the increasing global demand for clean energy. This includes providing the necessary infrastructure to power energy-intensive sectors such as artificial intelligence in a more sustainable way. By improving the accessibility and affordability of BESS technology, the partnership could play a role in accelerating the adoption of renewable power worldwide.

According to Jeffrey Shen, CEO of XP, the joint effort will accelerate Inno’s expansion within the energy storage market.

"Our collaboration with Jabil will accelerate Inno's growth in the energy storage market, bringing the potential of renewable power to more communities around the world, especially in support of the growing energy demand of AI infrastructures globally," Jeffrey explains.

"Together we can provide customers with increased supply chain resiliency at a competitive price point."

As the electrification of transport, buildings and industry continues to gain momentum a reliable supply of energy storage solutions is essential for meeting climate goals and achieving a decarbonised global economy.

Join Jabil at Procurement & Supply Chain LIVE

Fireside: Procurement is a value driver, not a cost centre, with Frank McKay, Chief Supply Chain Officer, and Graham Scott, Chief Procurement Officer at Jabil

Join Frank McKay at Procurement & Supply Chain LIVE: The US Summit in Chicago.

Frank serves as Chief Supply Chain Officer at Jabil, where he leads an organisation of approximately 3,000 employees across Asia, Europe and the Americas.

He has led the development of an optimised end-to-end supply chain, delivering value to customers and implementing intelligent supply chain strategies.

"I got the procurement bug and decided this was an area that would continue to evolve," Frank says. "It was a time when technology was just starting to become part of the ecosystem of procurement and supply chain."

name: EVs
title: IFC Invests $50M to Strengthen India's EV Battery Supply Chain with GFL Plant
description:
The investment will support the development of India’s first fully integrated battery-materials manufacturing facility in Gujarat, marking a significant step toward strengthening the country’s domestic battery supply chain.
Strategic Importance for India’s EV and Energy Storage Ecosystem The IFC investment is being widely viewed as a transformational development for India’s EV battery infrastructure.
GFL’s Vision to Build a World-Class Battery Materials Platform Gujarat Fluorochemicals, part of the INOXGFL Group, is rapidly emerging as a key player in India’s advanced materials and battery ecosystem.
The company aims to cover a significant portion of the battery bill of materials (BoM) required for lithium-ion battery manufacturing—positioning India as a serious global competitor in the battery supply chain.
Outlook: A Foundational Step for India’s EV Supply Chain With global battery supply chains facing geopolitical risks and raw-material constraints, the IFC-backed GFL project represents a foundational investment in India’s energy security and clean-mobility future.
text:
In a major boost to India’s electric vehicle (EV) and clean-energy ecosystem, the International Finance Corporation (IFC), the private-sector arm of the World Bank Group, has committed $50 million in funding to GFCL EV Products Ltd, a subsidiary of Gujarat Fluorochemicals Ltd (GFL). The investment will support the development of India’s first fully integrated battery-materials manufacturing facility in Gujarat, marking a significant step toward strengthening the country’s domestic battery supply chain.

The project aligns with India’s long-term goals of reducing import dependence, accelerating EV adoption, and building a globally competitive clean-energy manufacturing ecosystem.

First Integrated Battery Materials Plant in India to Come Up in Gujarat

The greenfield facility will be set up at Jolva near Bharuch in Gujarat and will manufacture a comprehensive range of advanced battery materials required for lithium-ion battery production. These include:

Electrolyte salts such as LiPF₆

Electrolyte formulations

Lithium Iron Phosphate (LFP) cathode active materials

PVDF and PTFE binders

Other critical battery chemicals used in EVs and energy-storage systems

Once operational, the facility is expected to significantly localise the battery materials value chain, which currently depends heavily on imports.

Strategic Importance for India’s EV and Energy Storage Ecosystem

The IFC investment is being widely viewed as a transformational development for India’s EV battery infrastructure. By enabling large-scale domestic manufacturing of battery materials, the project will:

Reduce India’s dependence on imported battery components

Strengthen supply-chain security for EV manufacturers

Lower production costs over time

Support rapid electrification across passenger vehicles, commercial fleets and energy-storage applications

The investment also aligns with national initiatives such as Make in India, Atmanirbhar Bharat, and India’s net-zero commitments.

IFC’s First Battery Materials Investment in India

This marks IFC’s first direct investment into a battery-materials manufacturing company in India, underlining growing international confidence in the country’s clean-mobility transition. The funding is being made through compulsorily convertible instruments, which will eventually be converted into equity in GFCL EV Products.

IFC’s participation not only provides capital but also enhances the project’s global credibility, helping attract future international financing and partnerships.

GFL’s Vision to Build a World-Class Battery Materials Platform

Gujarat Fluorochemicals, part of the INOXGFL Group, is rapidly emerging as a key player in India’s advanced materials and battery ecosystem. Through its subsidiary, GFCL EV Products, the company is working towards building a large-scale, integrated battery-materials platform capable of serving both domestic and global markets.

The company aims to cover a significant portion of the battery bill of materials (BoM) required for lithium-ion battery manufacturing—positioning India as a serious global competitor in the battery supply chain.

Boost to India’s EV Manufacturing and Clean Energy Ambitions

The new battery-materials facility is expected to:

Accelerate EV production across two-wheelers, three-wheelers, cars and commercial vehicles

Support the fast-growing energy-storage sector for renewable integration

Generate high-value manufacturing jobs

Encourage further foreign investments into India’s EV supply chain

Strengthen India’s position as a future global hub for battery materials and advanced chemistry manufacturing

As EV adoption surges across India, access to domestically sourced battery materials will be critical to ensuring sustainable, cost-competitive, and scalable growth.

Outlook: A Foundational Step for India’s EV Supply Chain

With global battery supply chains facing geopolitical risks and raw-material constraints, the IFC-backed GFL project represents a foundational investment in India’s energy security and clean-mobility future. As domestic EV demand continues to rise and gigafactory investments expand, integrated battery-materials manufacturing will become a cornerstone of India’s next phase of industrial growth.

description:

You mentioned Virginia—whole sections of the state are opposing high-voltage transmission projects proposed to serve data centers.
In Virginia, as you pointed out, candidates ran against data centers, saying they'll make them pay their fair share.
While they may not be able to say this is all for data centers, to them it doesn't matter.
Right now, it's sort of the NIMBY idea: we don't want data centers; big tech are the bad people; utilities are also bad.
text:
December 5, 2025 – What if the future of war, politics, and your electric bill were all connected? In this must-hear conversation, veteran host Jim Puplava sits down with acclaimed energy expert and author Robert Bryce to expose the hidden battle for power—literally and figuratively—shaping today's world. From Ukraine’s grid warfare to skyrocketing U.S. utility prices and the explosive growth of AI data centers, they reveal how electricity is at the heart of global conflict, economic uncertainty, and the upcoming election. Don’t miss these sharp insights, real-world stories, and urgent questions about how we’ll keep the lights on in the decade ahead. Have any feedback, breaking news, or comments about today's show? Click here to send us a message.

Column: Robert Bryce | Substack

Related article: The Electricity War - Robert Bryce

Website: Robert Bryce - Author | Journalist

Recent book: A Question of Power: Electricity and the Wealth of Nations

YouTube channel: Robert Bryce - YouTube

X: @pwrhungry

To speak with any of our wealth advisors, feel free to Contact Us online or give us a call at (888) 486-3939.

Stay ahead of the news! Subscribe to our premium weekday podcast

Ways to follow us

Client website: Financial Sense Wealth Management

X: Financial Sense (@FinancialSense_) / X

LinkedIn: Financial Sense® Wealth Management: Overview | LinkedIn

YouTube: Financial Sense - YouTube

Apple Podcasts:Financial Sense Newshour - Podcast - Apple Podcasts

Spotify: Financial Sense(R) Newshour | Podcast on Spotify

Summary

Electricity as a Weapon: The Russia-Ukraine war marks the first major conflict where control of electricity infrastructure is central to military strategy and peace negotiations.

Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Plant: Never before has a power plant been part of a peace deal—Russia’s demand for half the output is unprecedented.

Grid Vulnerability: Both Ukraine and Russia are targeting each other’s power grids and energy facilities, with over 1,300 strikes reported against Ukraine’s sector alone.

Energy & Society: Disabling a nation’s electric grid cripples hospitals, emergency services, water, manufacturing, and the ability to wage war.

Rising U.S. Utility Rates: Electricity prices are spiking nationwide, driven by flat supply, soaring demand from AI data centers, and costly policies favoring wind, solar, and batteries.

Land Use Conflicts: Rapid expansion of high-voltage transmission lines, data centers, and renewable projects faces growing local opposition and regulatory hurdles.

Natural Gas Dominance: Despite hopes for nuclear, the U.S. is set to meet surging demand with new natural gas plants, not rapid nuclear deployment.

Labor & Supply Chain Shortages: Construction of new energy infrastructure is being slowed by skilled labor shortages and dependence on critical minerals from abroad.

Political Impact: Electricity affordability is emerging as a top issue for 2025 elections, crossing partisan lines and fueling debates about technology, energy policy, and the future of American industry.

Commodities & the Future: The drive to reshape the U.S. grid, reindustrialize, and support tech growth hinges on access to commodities like copper, uranium, and rare earths.

Transcript

Jim Puplava:

Well, if you've been following the news, you know the President is trying to meet with Putin and bring about a peace agreement for the Ukraine war. Jim Puplava:

Yeah, well, it looks like, at least from what I'm following, it could be Newsom and AOC. Among the candidates, Newsom seems to be at the top right now.

Robert Bryce:

He has the money, he's from a big state with a lot of electoral votes. He says he hasn't decided—he's decided. But he's from California, and as you say, the land of fruits and nuts. I think Republicans will say, "Do you really want a California-style regime nationally with all these insane climate policies?" They can point to his record on housing, a lot of things—he's vulnerable on his own record. There's no doubt the Democratic Party has moved further left and is now really the party of AOC, but Newsom—don't count him out. He's movie-star handsome, very good on the stump, but it's going to be a battle royale on the Republican side.

Jim Puplava:

Well, we live in interesting times. I'm just glad I own hard assets for my clients and we own some growth utilities. It's a different market. That's one of the things I've seen in the market over the years—every decade brings a different kind of cycle, stocks that drive it. Right now, I see the drive in commodity-type stocks. But anyway, as always, it's a pleasure having you on the program. I read your article, "The Electricity War," and I hadn't heard anyone talk about that. So I wanted to have you on. You're my electricity man, my expert buddy.

Robert Bryce:

That's very kind, thanks. Don't forget robertbryce.substack.com.

Jim Puplava:

Hey Robert, tell them about your two documentary films—they're excellent. If you really want to understand electricity and what's going on, people should go watch them. They're very interesting and well done.

Robert Bryce:

Thank you. I've actually made a couple of mini-documentaries—"mini docs"—with my daughter Mary. One is "Shrinking Fission" on SMRs, about seven minutes. We also made one earlier this year called "Sunblock: The Global Fight to Save Farmland from Big Solar." I also did a feature-length documentary in 2019 with Tyson Culver called "Juice: How Electricity Explains the World"—that's at juicethemovie.com. Then we did a five-part docuseries called "Juice: Power, Politics, and the Grid." Each segment's about 20 minutes, available at juicetheseries.com. All are free on YouTube. I'm easy to find—just search Robert Bryce on YouTube or Google. Thank you. I'm very proud of all the documentaries we've done—I'm very lucky to do what I do. It's my purpose and my passion, and I love to talk about this stuff.

Jim Puplava:

Well, you're very good at it, so I appreciate you coming on the program. Happy holidays, Merry Christmas, and a prosperous new year.

Robert Bryce:

Awesome. Thanks, Jim.

Article content

Electric vehicles produce more pollution than the gas-powered cars they’re replacing.

Article content

tap here to see other videos from our team.

Article content

This revelation, emerging from life-cycle and supply chain audits, exposes the false claim behind Ottawa’s more than $50 billion experiment. A Volvo study found that manufacturing an EV generates 70 per cent more emissions than building a comparable conventional vehicle because battery production is energy-intensive and often powered by coal in countries such as China. Depending on the electricity grid, it can take years or never for an EV to offset that initial carbon debt.

Prime Minister Mark Carney paused the federal electric vehicle (EV) mandate for 2026 due to public pressure and corporate failures while keeping the 2030 and 2035 targets. The mandate requires 20 per cent of new vehicles sold in 2026 to be zero-emission, rising to 60 per cent in 2030 and 100 per cent in 2035. Carney inherited this policy crisis but is reluctant to abandon it.

Article content

Advertisement 3

Story continues below

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content

Industry failures and Trump tariffs forced Ottawa’s hand. Northvolt received $240 million in federal subsidies for a Quebec battery plant before filing for bankruptcy. Lion Electric burned through $100 million before announcing layoffs. Arrival, a U.K.-based electric van and bus manufacturer, collapsed entirely. Stellantis and LG Energy Solution extracted $15 billion for Windsor. Volkswagen secured $13 billion for St. Thomas.

The federal government committed more than $50 billion in subsidies and tax credits to prop up Canada’s EV industry. Ottawa defended these payouts as necessary to match the U.S. Inflation Reduction Act, which offers major incentives for EV and battery manufacturing. That is twice Manitoba’s annual operating budget. Every Manitoban could have had a two-year tax holiday with the public money Ottawa wasted on EVs.

Advertisement 4

Story continues below

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content

Even with incentives, EVs reached only 15 per cent of new vehicle sales in 2024, far short of the mandated levels for 2026 and 2030. When federal subsidies ended in January 2025, sales collapsed to nine per cent, revealing the true level of consumer demand. Dealer lots overflowed with unsold inventory. EV sales also slowed in the U.S. and Europe in 2024, showing that cooling demand is a broader trend.

As economist Friedrich Hayek observed, “The curious task of economics is to demonstrate to men how little they really know about what they imagine they can design.” Politicians and bureaucrats cannot know what millions of Canadians know about their own needs. When federal ministers mandate which vehicles Canadians must buy and which companies deserve billions, they substitute the judgment of a few hundred officials for the collective wisdom of an entire market.

Advertisement 5

Story continues below

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content

Bureaucrats draft regulations that determine the vehicles Canadians must purchase years from now, as if they can predict technology and consumer preferences better than markets.

Green ideology provided perfect cover. Invoke a climate emergency and fiscal responsibility vanishes. Question more than $50 billion in subsidies and you are labelled a climate denier. Point out the environmental costs of battery production, and you are accused of spreading misinformation.

History repeatedly teaches that central planning always fails. Soviet five-year plans, Venezuela’s resource nationalization and Britain’s industrial policy failures all show the same pattern. Every attempt to run economies from political offices ends in misallocation, waste and outcomes opposite to those promised. Concentrated political power cannot ever match the intelligence of free markets responding to real prices and constraints.

Advertisement 6

Story continues below

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content

Markets collect information that no central planner can access. Prices signal scarcity and value. Profits and losses reward accuracy and punish error. When governments override these mechanisms with mandates and subsidies, they impair the information system that enables rational economic decisions.

The EV mandate forced a technological shift and failed. Billions in subsidies went to failing companies. Taxpayers absorbed losses while corporations walked away. Workers lost their jobs.

Canada needs a full repeal of the EV mandate and a retreat from PMO planners directing market decisions. The law must be struck, not paused. The contrived 2030 and 2035 targets must be abandoned.

Markets, not cabinet ministers, must determine what technologies Canadians choose.

– Marco Navarro-Genie is vice-president of research at the Frontier Centre for Public Policy and co-author, with Barry Cooper, of Canada’s COVID: The Story of a Pandemic Moral Panic (2023).

name: Clean Energy
title: Economic benefits of fighting climate change outweigh inaction - The Augusta Chronicle
description:
Here are some benefits of fighting climate change from various sources, including Yale Climate Connections.
The benefits of fighting climate change Cleaner air leads to fewer pollution-related illnesses, which means less money spent on medical treatments and fewer hospital admissions.
Here are some ways climate change impacts daily life from various sources, including the Environmental Defense Fund.
By reducing emissions, climate action lessens the frequency and intensity of these costly disruptions.
Erica Van Buren is the climate change reporter for The Augusta Chronicle, part of the USA TODAY Network.
text:
As greenhouse gas emissions surround the Earth, they trap the sun’s heat. Because of this, the planet is warming up, and the climate is changing, according to experts.

The world is now warming faster than at any point in recorded history. Warmer temperatures over time are changing weather patterns. This poses many risks to all forms of life, according to the United Nations Climate Action.

Here are some benefits of fighting climate change from various sources, including Yale Climate Connections.

The benefits of fighting climate change

Cleaner air leads to fewer pollution-related illnesses, which means less money spent on medical treatments and fewer hospital admissions.

Reducing emissions helps prevent crop losses, which can save billions of dollars annually and enhance food security.

Transitioning to clean energy means investment in building new infrastructure like solar, wind farms, and manufacturing clean vehicles, creating demand for skilled jobs like engineers, electricians, and construction workers.

In most parts of the world, new renewable energy projects are already the most affordable source of power.

Energy efficiency upgrades in homes and buildings can lead to substantial reductions in energy bills for households.

Investing in clean energy can decouple economies from the volatile price swings and geopolitical shocks of the global fossil fuel market.

Here are some ways climate change impacts daily life from various sources, including the Environmental Defense Fund.

Higher grocery prices due to crop failures.

Increased energy bills from heatwaves.

Infrastructure damage from floods.

Health risks include heat stress and respiratory issues.

Inaction on climate change exposes economies to massive costs from extreme weather events, infrastructure damage, and agricultural losses, according to the World Resources Institute. The global economic benefits from avoided damages and short-term improvements could increase globally by up to 3% by 2050.

By reducing emissions, climate action lessens the frequency and intensity of these costly disruptions.

Taking climate action in the United States can save at least $4 billion by the end of the century on road maintenance alone, according to Yale Climate Connections.

This reporting content is supported by a partnership with several funders and Journalism Funding Partners.

Erica Van Buren is the climate change reporter for The Augusta Chronicle, part of the USA TODAY Network. Connect with her at EVanBuren@gannett.com or on X: @EricaVanBuren32.

name: Clean Energy
title: State needs more energy, sensible regulation - Williamsport Sun-Gazette
description:
In July, nearly two dozen companies gathered in Pittsburgh, along with President Donald Trump and other leaders, to announce investments in data centers and needed energy infrastructure.
data centers addressing water and energy use, emergency preparedness,” and more.
At a hearing before the Pennsylvania House Committee on Energy, several witnesses cautioned against the bill’s renewable mandate.
Josh Shapiro should drop his own attempts to tax reliable energy sources and force renewable energy on consumers.
Or are we truly going to work toward Pennsylvania energy dominance?
text:
In July, nearly two dozen companies gathered in Pittsburgh, along with President Donald Trump and other leaders, to announce investments in data centers and needed energy infrastructure. Totaling more than $90 billion, the expenditures would equal nearly ten percent of Pennsylvania’s gross domestic product, inducing a headline that described the prospect as “truly mind-blowing.”

Since then, some have begun erecting regulatory obstacles to this development. Presented as consumer protections, many are more likely to be economy killers — and “mind-blowing” for would-be reformers of 164,000 regulations already dampening Pennsylvania’s business climate.

Consider a six-bill package introduced by seven Democrat members of the Pennsylvania House of Representatives “to encourage the responsible development of A.I. data centers addressing water and energy use, emergency preparedness,” and more.

Pennsylvania has power plants, steel mills, factories, coal mines, and acres of warehouses–all of which deal with a host of regulations to address these same issues. One bill would impose energy-efficiency standards on data centers when there is no more powerful incentive for prudent use of resources than the profit motive.

Why are lawmakers specifically targeting these information processors?

“This is an attempt to throttle new data centers to prevent more natural gas from being used to power them,” writes Jim Willis, publisher of Marcellus Drilling News. “‘Responsible development’ is code for no development.”

A seventh House bill, titled the “Data Center Act,” would require the eponymous facilities to get at least 25 percent of their energy from so-called renewable sources, defined as wind, solar, biomass, and hydroelectric.

Such market meddling has contributed to rising electricity prices and a more fragile power grid by giving preferential treatment to expensive and unreliable energy sources–particularly wind and solar. Moreover, misguided policies have shortened or ended operations for more practical technologies, such as coal- and natural gas-fired power plants.

At a hearing before the Pennsylvania House Committee on Energy, several witnesses cautioned against the bill’s renewable mandate. They included Stephen DeFrank, chairman of the state Public Utility Commission; Joe Bowring, an independent market monitor with PJM Interconnection; Dr. Amy Brinton, director of government affairs with the Pennsylvania Chamber of Business and Industry; Rob Bair, president of the Pennsylvania Building and Construction Trades Council; and Dan Diorio, vice president of state policy with the Data Center Coalition.

State Rep. Mike Armanini, one of at least two Republican committee members opposing the mandate, noted that a 2019 proposal by then-Gov. Tom Wolf to impose a tax on fossil fuels had discouraged investment in natural gas plants. He also said that another House committee “would kill the natural gas industry” with a proposal to establish a gas-well setback of nearly a mile.

State Rep. Rob Matzie, a Democrat and the bill’s prime sponsor, agreed that avoiding overregulation was important. But Matzie insisted that policymakers should “promulgate some regulations early from a temporary perspective, and then move forward.”

Perhaps Matzie is testing political winds with the mandate provision. However, once enacted, most regulations are about as “temporary” as the Great Pyramid of Giza.

Enacted two decades ago, the state’s Alternative Energy Portfolio Standards Act (AEPS) cost electricity customers more than $700 million in 2024 in compliance costs alone. Meanwhile, the wind and solar energy it subsidizes remains unreliable and too expensive to survive in a free market.

In Arizona, regulators have voted unanimously to begin repealing that state’s version of AEPS, reports the American Legislative Exchange Council (ALEC). Rating states based on various policies, ALEC ranks Arizona near the top nationally, at second and sixth for economic performance and economic outlook, respectively. On the other hand, Pennsylvania’s rankings are a pathetic 44th and 36th.

Noting Arizona’s economic success, ALEC partially credits the state’s “infrastructure capacity to support resource-intensive industries,” such as data centers that “require dependable, uninterrupted sources of baseload electricity to stay operational.”

If there is to be legislation on data centers, a proposal by state Sen. Camera Bartolotta offers a more viable solution. Barlotta’s bill would expedite permits for projects that meet or exceed federal standards.

Better still would be fulfilling the promise of broad permitting reform in a recent budget agreement. And while budget negotiations ended the threatened implementation of Wolf’s 2019 tax on fossil fuels, Gov. Josh Shapiro should drop his own attempts to tax reliable energy sources and force renewable energy on consumers.

As Rep. Armanini put it: “What are we going to do with Pennsylvania? Are we going to overregulate it and not let [the energy] industry grow? Or are we truly going to work toward Pennsylvania energy dominance? … We need to get into the game of being competitive.”

A competitive Pennsylvania is not out of reach. Thankfully, regulatory reform found its way into the newly minted state budget, suggesting the push for commonsense regulation is quickly gaining momentum in Harrisburg.

Gordon Tomb is a senior fellow with the Commonwealth Foundation, a free-market think tank in Pennsylvania.

name: Texas American Energy
title: Energy storage industry set aggressive goals for 2025 — and already crushed them
description:
So how’d the storage industry do?
In eight years, energy storage went from a tiny player to one of the largest sources of new power on the U.S. grid.
Experts say that lessons learned there can help other regions deploy battery storage onto their grids, including the Midwest and East Coast, which are buckling under the weight of new data center construction.
Sizable Energy is working on a novel way to store power in flexible reservoirs that float in the open ocean.
And, Cache Energy has developed inexpensive pellets of calcium hydroxide that could store energy for months with minimal losses.
text:
Nearly a decade ago, when the energy storage market was in its infancy, an industry organization set a dreamy goal: By the end of 2025, the U.S. would deploy 35 gigawatts of batteries connected to the grid.

So how’d the storage industry do? In the third quarter, 4.7 gigawatts of batteries were installed. In sum, more than 40 gigawatts have been deployed, and the year isn’t over, Canary Media reported. In eight years, energy storage went from a tiny player to one of the largest sources of new power on the U.S. grid.

What’s more, that’s nearly half of all new renewable power deployed on the grid for July through September, and this year, renewables have been the leading source of all new capacity, according to the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission.

Much of the new storage capacity has been deployed in Arizona, California, and Texas, states where the grid has been strained in recent years. Experts say that lessons learned there can help other regions deploy battery storage onto their grids, including the Midwest and East Coast, which are buckling under the weight of new data center construction.

Startups have been taking note.

Redwood Materials, which was co-founded by Tesla alumnus JB Straubel, in June added a new business line focused on repurposing used EV batteries for grid-scale storage. The company noticed two overlapping trends: The batteries that were arriving at its recycling facilities still had plenty of life left in them, and meanwhile, the battery storage industry was growing in leaps and bounds.

By 2028, Redwood plans to deploy 20 gigawatt-hours’ worth of battery storage. Investors have voiced their approval, investing another $350 million in the company to propel the new business line.

Another startup, Base Power, has taken a slightly different tack, leasing batteries to homeowners and aggregating them to serve as a large virtual power plant. The Austin-based startup raised $1 billion in October to help build a battery factory and fuel its expansion beyond Texas. The company has deployed more than 100 megawatt-hours of batteries in Texas.

While lithium-ion batteries have dominated new installations, other startups are pursuing other technologies that could lower storage costs significantly.

Sizable Energy is working on a novel way to store power in flexible reservoirs that float in the open ocean. Fourth Power is using blocks of carbon to store heat at super-high temperatures, and it’s looking to deploy them in 2028 at a cost that’s lower than lithium-ion batteries or peaking natural gas power plants. XL Batteries is deploying its flow-battery technology at petrochemical storage sites, allowing it to store hundreds of megawatt-hours using existing infrastructure. And, Cache Energy has developed inexpensive pellets of calcium hydroxide that could store energy for months with minimal losses.
